word.name: abase
word.sentence: Anna expected to have to curtsy to the King of Siam; when told to cast herself down on the ground before him, however, she refused to abase herself.

word.name: abash
word.sentence: He was not at all abashed by her open admiration.

word.name: abate
word.sentence: Rather than leaving immediately, they waited for the storm to abate.

word.name: abbreviate
word.sentence: Because we were running out of time, the lecturer had to abbreviate her speech.

word.name: abdicate
word.sentence: When Edward VIII abdicated the British throne, he surprised the entire world.

word.name: aberrant
word.sentence: Given the aberrant nature of the data, we came to doubt the validity of the entire experiment.

word.name: aberration
word.defn: abnormality; departure from the norm; mental irregularity or disorder
word.sentence: It remains the consensus among investors on Wall Street that current high oil prices are a temporary aberration and that we shall soon see a return to cheap oil.

word.name: abet
word.defn: assist, usually in doing somethign wrong; encourage
word.sentence: She was unwilling to abet him in the swindle he had planned.

word.name: abeyance
word.sentence: The deal was held in abeyance until her arrival.

word.name: abhor
word.sentence: She abhorred all forms of bigotry.

word.name: abject
word.sentence: On the streets of New York the homeless live in abject poverty, huddling in doorways to find shelter from the wind.

word.name: abjure
word.sentence: Pressure from university authorities caused the young scholar to abjure his heretical opinions.

word.name: ablution
word.sentence: His daily ablutions were accompanied by loud noises that he humorously labeled "Opera in the Bath."

word.name: abnegation
word.sentence: Though Rudolph and Duchess Flavia loved one another, their love was doomed, for she had to wed the king; their act of abnegation was necessary to preserve th kingdom.

word.name: abolish
word.sentence: The president of the college refused to abolish the physical education requirement.

word.name: abominable
word.sentence: Mary liked John until she learned he was also dating Susan; then she called him an abominable young man, with abominable taste in women.

word.name: abominate
word.sentence: Moses scolded the idol worshippers in the tribe because he abominated the custom.

word.name: aboriginal
word.defn: being the first of its kind in a region; primitive; native
word.sentence: Her studies of the primitive art forms of the aboriginal indians were widely reported in the scientific journals.

word.name: abortive
word.sentence: Attacked by armed troops, the Chinese students had to abandon their abortive attempt to democratize Beijing peacefully.

word.name: abrasive
word.defn: rubbing away; tending to grind down
word.sentence: Just as abrasive cleaning powders can wear away a shiny finish, abrasive remarks can wear away a listener's patience.

word.name: abridge
word.sentence: Because the publishers felt the public wanted a shorter version of War and Peace, they proceeded to abridge the novel.

word.name: abrogate
word.sentence: The king intended to abrogate the decree issued by his predecessor.

word.name: abscission
word.defn: removal by cutting off, as in surgery; separation
word.sentence: Gas gangrene spreads so swiftly and is so potentially deadly that doctors advise abscission of teh gangrenous tissue. When a flower or leaf separates naturally from the parent plant, this process is called abscission or leaf fall.

word.name: abscond
word.sentence: The teller who absconded with the bonds went uncaptured until someone recognized him from his photograph on America's Most Wanted.

word.name: absolute
word.sentence: Although the King of Siam was an absolute monarch, he did not watn to behead his unfaithful wife without absolute evidence of her infidelity.

word.name: absolve
word.sentence: The father confessor absolved him of his sins.

word.name: abstain
word.sentence: After considering the effect of alcohol on his athletic performance, he decided to abstain from drinking while he trained for the race.

word.name: abstemious
word.defn: sparing in eating and drinking; temperate
word.sentence: Concerned whether her vegetarian son's abstemious diet provided him with sufficient protein, the worried mother pressed food on him.

word.name: abstinence
word.sentence: The doctor recommended total abstinence from salted foods.

word.name: abstract
word.sentence: To him, hunger was an abstract concept; he had never missed a meal.

word.name: abstruse
word.sentence: Baffled by the abstruse philosophical texts assigned in class, Dave asked Lexy to explain Kant's Critique of Pure Reason.

word.name: abusive
word.sentence: An abusive parent damages a child both mentally and physically.

word.name: abut
word.sentence: Where our estates abut, we must build a fence.

word.name: abysmal
word.sentence: His arrogance is exceeded only by his abysmal ignorance.

word.name: abyss
word.sentence: Darth Vader seized the evil emperor and hurled him into the abyss.

word.name: academic
word.defn: related to a school; not practical or directly useful
word.sentence: The dean's talk about reforming academic policies was only an academic discussion: we knew little, if anything, would change.

word.name: accede
word.sentence: If I accede to this demand for black-mail, I am afraid that I will be th victim of future demands.

word.name: accelerate
word.sentence: In our science class, we learn how falling bodies accelerate.

word.name: accessible
word.sentence: We asked our guide whether the ruins were accessible on foot.

word.name: accessory
word.defn: additional object; useful but not essential thing
word.sentence: She bought an attractive handbag as an accessory for her dress.

word.name: acclaim
word.sentence: The sportscasters acclaimed every American victory in the Olympics and decried every American defeat.

word.name: acclimate
word.defn: adjust to climate or environment; adapt
word.sentence: One of the difficulties of our present air age is the need of travelers to acclimate themselves to their new and often strange environments.

word.name: acclivity
word.sentence: The car could not go up the acclivity in high gear.

word.name: accolade
word.sentence: In Hollywood, an "Oscar" is the highest accolade.

word.name: accommodate
word.defn: oblige or help someone; adjust or bring into harmony; adapt
word.sentence: Mitch always did everything possible to accommodate his elderly relatives, from driving them to medical appointments to helping them with paperwork.

word.name: accomplice
word.sentence: Because he had provided the criminal with the lethal weapon, he was arrested as an accomplice in the murder.

word.name: accord
word.sentence: She was in complete accord with the verdict.

word.name: accost
word.defn: approach and speak first to a person
word.sentence: When the two young men accosted me, I was frightened because I thought they were going to attack me.

word.name: accoutre
word.sentence: The fisherman was accoutred with the best that the sporting goods store could supply.

word.name: accretion
word.sentence: Over the years Bob put on weight; because of this accretion of flesh, he went from size M to size XL.

word.name: accrue
word.sentence: You must pay the interest that has accrued on your debt as well as the principal sum.

word.name: acerbic
word.defn: bitter or sour in nature; sharp and cutting
word.sentence: Noted for her acerbic with and gossiping. Alice Roosevelt Longworth had a pillow in her home embroidered with the legend "If you can't say something good about someone, sit right here by me."

word.name: acerbity
word.sentence: The meeting of the United Nations Assembly was marked with such acerbity that observers held little hope of reaching any useful settlement of the problem.

word.name: acetic
word.sentence: The salad had an exceedingly acetic flavor.

word.name: acidulous
word.sentence: James was unpopular because of his sarcastic and acidulous remarks.

word.name: acknowledge
word.sentence: Although I acknowledge that the Beatles' tunes sounds pretty dated nowadays, I still prefer them to the gangsta rap songs my brothers play.

word.name: acme
word.sentence: Welles's success in Citizen kane marked the acme of his career as an actor; never again did he achieve such popular acclaim.

word.name: acoustics
word.defn: science of sounds; quality that makes a room easy or hard to hear in
word.sentence: Carnegie Hall is liked by music lovers because of its fine acoustics.

word.name: acquiesce
word.sentence: Although she appeared to acquiesce to her employer's suggestings, I could tell she had reservations about the changes he wanted made.

word.name: acquittal
word.sentence: His acquittal by the jury surprised those who had thought him guilty.

word.name: acrid
word.sentence: The acrid odor of burnt gunpowder filled the room after the pistol had been fired.

word.name: acrimonious
word.sentence: The candidate attacked his opponent in highly acrimonious temrs.

word.name: acrophobia
word.sentence: A born salesman, he could convince someone with a bad case of acrophobia to sign up for a life memberhship in a sky-diving club.

word.name: actuarial
word.sentence: Accordign to recent actuarial tables, life expectancy is greater today than it was a century ago.

word.name: actuate
word.sentence: I fail to understand what actuated you to reply to this letter so nastily.

word.name: accumen
word.sentence: Her business acumen helped her to succeed where others had failed.

word.name: acute
word.defn: quickly perceptive; keen; brief and severe
word.sentence: The acute young doctor realized immediately that the gradual deterioration of her patient's once-acute hearing was due to a chronic illness, not an acute one.

word.name: adage
word.sentence: There is much truth in the old adage aobout fools and their money.

word.name: adamant
word.sentence: In this movie Bronson played the part of a revenge-driven man, adamant in his determination to punish the criminals who destroyed his family.

word.name: adapt
word.sentence: Some species of animals have become extinct because they could not adapt to a changing environment.

word.name: addendum
word.sentence: Jane's editor approved her new comparative literature text but thought it would be even better with an addendum on recent developments in literary crticism.

word.name: addiction
word.sentence: His addiction to drugs caused his friends much grief.

word.name: addle
word.sentence: This idiotic plan is confusing enough to addle anyone.

word.name: address
word.defn: direct a speech to; deal with or discuss
word.sentence: Due to address the convention in July, Brown planned to address the issue of low-income housing in his speech.

word.name: adept
word.sentence: She was adept at the fine art of irritating people.

word.name: adhere
word.sentence: I will adhere to this opinion until proof that I am wrong is presented.

word.name: adherent
word.sentence: In the wake of the scandal, the senator's one-time adherents quietly deserted him.

word.name: adjacent
word.sentence: Philip's best friend Jason lived only four houses down the block, near but not immediately adjacent.

word.name: adjunct
word.defn: something (generally nonessential or inferior) added on or attached
word.sentence: Although I don't absolutely need a second computer, I plan to buy a laptop to serve as an adjunct to my desktop model.

word.name: adjuration
word.sentence: Her adjuration to tell the truth did not change the witnesses' testimony.

word.name: adjutant
word.defn: staff officer assisting the commander; assistant
word.sentence: Though Wellington delegated many tasks to his chief adjutant, Lord Fitzroy Somerset, Somerset was in no doubt as to who made all major decisions.

word.name: admonish
word.sentence: When her courtiers questioned her religious beliefs, Mary Stuart admonished them, declaring that she would worship as she pleased.

word.name: adorn
word.sentence: Wall paintings and carved statues adorned the temple.

word.name: adroit
word.sentence: Her adroit handling of the delicate situation pleased her employers.
